title: 109_s3688
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk as follows:

"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Mt. Soledad Veterans Memorial in San Diego, California, has honored US Armed Forces members for over 52 years. It was dedicated in 1954 as a tribute to those who died in World Wars and the Korean conflict, now commemorating veterans of all wars, including the War on Terrorism. The memorial features a cross, reflecting the US tradition of using religious emblems to honor fallen soldiers. The Mt. Soledad Veterans Memorial in San Diego is a multi-faceted memorial with secular symbols. It provides solace to veterans' families and comrades, recognized as a National Veterans Memorial by Congress. Despite 76% voter support to donate it to the Federal Government, a court ruling invalidated the decision. The City of San Diego is fighting to preserve the memorial for those who have served. The Mt. Soledad Veterans Memorial in San Diego, recognized as a National Veterans Memorial by Congress, is facing a court order to remove the Memorial Cross from city property by August 1, 2006. Congressional action is needed to preserve the memorial for past and future service members. The Mt. Soledad Veterans Memorial in San Diego, a National Veterans Memorial, is under threat of losing the Memorial Cross from city property by August 1, 2006. Congressional action is necessary to protect the memorial for current and future service members. The United States acquires the Mt. Soledad Veterans Memorial in San Diego to preserve it as a national memorial honoring veterans. Just compensation will be paid to the property owner for the property taken. The United States will pay just compensation for the acquisition of the Mt. Soledad Veterans Memorial. The Secretary of Defense will manage the property and enter into an agreement with the Mt. Soledad Memorial Association for maintenance. The Mt. Soledad Veterans Memorial is described as a portion of Pueblo lot 1265 in San Diego, California, with specific boundaries and measurements outlined. The Mt. Soledad Veterans Memorial, part of Pueblo lot 1265 in San Diego, has specific boundaries outlined in City Council Resolution No. 216644. The exact boundaries will be determined by a survey prepared by the Secretary of Defense, and expansion of the Memorial is prohibited upon acquisition by the United States.
